tit.e: Sanshoku suinin mondai (the question of the three alternative positions

sen.j: 三職推任問題（さんしょくすいにんもんだい）とは、天正10年（1582年）4月25日 (旧暦)、5月4日 (旧暦)両日付けの勧修寺晴豊の日記『晴豊公記（天正十年夏記）』の記事の解釈を巡る日本の歴史上の論争である。
sen.e: Sanshoku suinin mondai (三職推任問題) (three-post endorsement problem) is a controversy in relation to the interpretation of the articles in Haretoyo KAJUJI's diary "Haretoyo-koki (summer in the tenth year of Tensho)" (晴豊公記) dated April 25 (old calendar) and May 4 (old calendar) of 1582 (in the tenth year of Tensho).
sen.cmt: 「晴豊公記」→"Haretoyo-koki"(晴豊公記）[定訳不明]

sen.j: 織田信長は天正6年（1578年）4月に、右大臣兼右近衛大将を辞官して後、何らの官職に就いていなかった。
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA held no official title after resigning as Udaijin (Minister of the Right) and Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) in April, 1578.

sen.j: 天正10年5月に至り、朝廷から武田征伐の戦勝祝賀として信長に、太政大臣、関白、征夷大将軍の三職いずれかに推任しようとする動きがあった。
sen.e: In May, 1582, there was a move in the Imperial Court to endorse Nobunaga for one of the three posts, Grand Minister, Chancellor, or Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians) as a reward of his subjugation of Takeda.

In May, 1582, there was a move in the Imperial Court to endorse Nobunaga for one of the three posts, Grand Minister, Chancellor, or Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians) as a reward for his subjugation of Takeda.

In June (May in old lunar calendar), 1582, there was a move in the Imperial Court to endorse Nobunaga for one of the three posts, Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), or Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") as a reward for his subjugation of Takeda.
sen.cmt: 太政大臣、関白、征夷大将軍の定訳May→June (May in old lunar calendar)に変更しました。

sen.j: 本論争は直接的には、この動きを信長の強制と見るか否かを争うものであるが、その論を立脚点とした織田政権の将来構想や本能寺の変の背景に対する考察を含むものである。
sen.e: The point of the argument is whether the move was forced by Nobunaga or not, and also the issues include considerations to the grand plan of Oda administration and the background of the Honnoji Incident, which could be derived from the main argument.

sen.j: 従来伝承されていた『晴豊公記』は、天正10年4月分から同年9月分が欠けていたが、1968年（昭和43年）岩沢愿彦が内閣文庫（現国立公文書館）にあった『天正十年夏記』が『晴豊公記』断簡であることを発表した。
sen.e: "Haretoyo-koki" that had been handed down had missing pages of April to September in 1582, but in 1968 Yoshihiko IWASAWA released that "The Record of Summer in 1582" (天正十年夏記) he found out in Naikaku-bunko (literally, "Library of the Cabinet," National Archives of Japan now) was a fragment of "Haretoyo-koki."

sen.j: 岩沢の解釈では、「太政大臣、関白、将軍の三職いずれかに推任するのがよい」と言った主体を天皇の意向を受けた晴豊としており、以後もこの解釈を受け、信長はこの天皇の意向を突っぱねたとする説が通説化していた。
sen.e: Iwasawa's interpretation of the line 'he should be endorsed for Grand Minister, Chancellor, or Shogun' was that it was Haretoyo who said it in line with the Emperor's wish, and later this interpretation prevailed to form a common belief that Nobunaga refused the Emperor's wish.

sen.j: ところが、歴史研究家の立花京子が晴豊の日記全体の「被申候」使用例を分析した結果、村井貞勝の言葉と解釈し、独断専行を嫌う信長に無断で貞勝が発言するはずがないとし、信長の将軍任官の意向を踏まえたものであったと主張したことにより、歴史学者の間で賛否両論の論争となった。
sen.e: However, Kyoko TACHIBANA, a researcher of history, studied usages of '被申候'in other passages of whole Haretoyo's diary to conclude it was what Sadakatsu MURAI said, and she argued that Sadakatsu would never say such a thing without Nobunaga's permission because Nobunaga disliked his followers' arbitrary decisions or executions, and that he represented Nobunaga's wish to gain the post, which led to controversies of pros and cons among historians.

sen.j: また立花説では、5月4日付けの記事にある「将軍になるべき」との晴豊の言葉を朝廷公式の意向であったとし、「御らん」（森成利）を派遣した信長の意図を真意を隠しわざと当惑して見せたものとする。
sen.e: Tachibana's interpretation also claims that Haretoyo's words 'should be the Shogun' in the article of May 4 were official intention of the Imperial Court, and Nobunaga intentionally expressed his false embarrassment concealing his true meaning by having 'Oran' (Naritoshi MORI) meet the envoy.

sen.j: 立花はこの解釈に基づき、三職推任を信長の勝利と位置づけ、朝廷が拒めなかったものとした。
sen.e: Based on this interpretation, Tachibana concluded that the three-post endorsement indicated Nobunaga's victory over the Imperial Court which was unable to decline.

sen.j: これは、2月に太政大臣に就任したばかりである近衛前久が5月に突如辞任していること、本能寺の変後の7月17日_(旧暦)に羽柴秀吉から毛利輝元に宛てられた手紙において、秀吉が信長のことを「大相国」と呼んでいるが、信長に対する太政大臣贈官が宮中で論じられたのは同年10月の事であること、加えてその結果出された贈官の宣命には「重而太政大臣」の語句があり、これを太政大臣の辞令が出されたのが2度目であると解釈して、1度目の辞令を三職推任問題の時に既に太政大臣就任の内諾を信長から得たことにより、非公式な内定が出されていたと解している。
sen.e: He thinks that informal decision of appointing Nobunaga as the Grand Minister had been already made after confirming his informal consent when Haretoyo talked about the three-post endorsement based on the following facts: Sakihisa KONOE, who assumed the Grand Minister in February, abruptly resigned in May; Hideyoshi called Nobunaga 'Daishokoku' (the Grand Minister) in his letter to Terumoto MORI on July 17 after the Honnoji Incident, while the formal discussion at court on granting a posthumous title of the Grand Minister to Nobunaga was in October; and the subsequently issued Emperor's order of the posthumous title for Nobunaga contained a word 'choji Dajodaijin' (重而太政大臣) (the Grand Minister again), which Hashimoto believed meant the second appointment of Nobunaga as Grand Minister.

sen.j: しかしながら堀新 (歴史学者)から出された反論では、同日記の5月4日 (旧暦)付けの記事や、『誠仁親王消息』などの資料から、三職いずれかなどという曖昧な推任をしたのは誰も信長の真意を理解していなかったための行動であり、貞勝と信長との間にこの件に関する打ち合わせをした形跡がないことなどから、三職推任は信長の意向とは言えず、5月4日の晴豊の言葉も晴豊個人の見解であるとした。
sen.e: Shin HORI (a historian) argued against these interpretations that Haretoyo expressed his own opinion on May 4 at that time and the three-post endorsement had nothing do to with Nobunaga's intention, because: the article of the diary dated May 4 and "Message from Imperial Prince Sanehito" (誠仁親王消息) suggest that such an unspecific three-post endorsement came from the situation that no one knew what Nobunaga wanted; and nothing suggests Nobunaga and Sadakatsu had talked about this matter.

sen.j: 堀説では、信長は天下統一まで任官できないとして右大臣兼右近衛大将を辞官しており統一前に任官する理由が立たないことを指摘し、信長には任官の意思はなく、律令体制に留まらず中華皇帝を指向していたと推察できるともしている。
sen.e: Hori pointed out that Nobunaga had resigned as Minister of the Right and Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards because he would not take any official post until his unification of the whole country, and Hori also said Nobunaga probably did not want any official post, and instead he had the aim of becoming an emperor outside the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government established in the beginning of the eighth century).
